numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph shows that a larger percentage of people who are 15-24 years old think that the world is getting better.
2. Many people in third-world countries are optimistic.
3. This optimism may mean that these countries receive more support.
4. This optimism may mean that these countries develop faster.
5. Older people are less optimistic about the world.
6. This fact suggests that experiences influence how a person views the world.
7. A person can have more experiences.
8. If a person has more experiences then the person can have more negative thoughts.
9. This fact may show that the world is not getting better.
10. A person who is 15-24 years old has less experience than an older person.
11. A person who is 15-24 years old may have less leverage because of this lack of experience.
12. Younger generations have seen less change in the world than older people.
13. A person who is 40 years old or older may be able to make a clearer judgement about whether the world is getting better.
14. No single generation conclusively thinks that the world is getting better.
15. Personal experiences can affect a person's judgement about whether the world is getting better.
16. Some personal experiences do not relate to the world as a whole.
17. I wonder whether we can ever say that the world is getting better.
18. I ask whether there will ever be a time when the statement that the world is getting better is true.
19. I am a member of Generation Z.
20. I have seen the personalities of my peers.
21. I say that Generation Z is forward-thinking.
22. I say that Generation Z is inclusive of all people.
23. This inclusiveness can help the world become better to some extent.
